verses.verse: Then at that time Pilate took Jesus and had him severely whipped,
and the soldiers twisted together a crown of thorns and put it on his head. Then they put a purple robe on him,
and kept saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!" They kept giving him blows with their hands, also.
Pilate therefore went out again and said to them, "Look, I bring him out to you, so that you may know that in him I find not even one fault."
Then Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. [Pilate] said to them, "Look at this man!"
When the chief priest and temple police saw him, they shouted, saying, "Crucify [him], crucify [him]." Pilate said to them, "You take and crucify him, for I find in him not even one fault."
The Jews answered him, "We have a law, and by our law he ought to die, because he made himself the Son of God."
When Pilate heard this news, he was even more afraid.
He returned to the Judgment Hall and said to Jesus, "Where are you from?" But Jesus gave no answer.
Pilate then said to him, "Aren't you going to speak to me? Don't you know that I have authority to crucify you and authority to release you?"
Jesus answered, "You would have not authority over me except it were given to you from above. Therefore he who delivered me to you has the greater sin."
From that time on, Pilate kept seeking to release him, but the Jews kept shouting, "If you let this man go, you are not Caesar's friend. Whoever makes himself a king speaks against Caesar."
Therefore Pilate heard that saying, he brought Jesus outside and sat down on the Judgment Seat in a place called the Pavement but in Hebrew, Gabbatha.
It was Preparation Day of the Passover, about the sixth hour [about noon], and he said to the Jews, "Look, your King!"
They shouted, "Take him away! Take him away! Crucify him!" Pilate said to them, "Shall I crucify your King?" The chief priests answered, "We have no king but Caesar!"
So he delivered him to them to be crucified, and they took Jesus and led him away.
Carrying his cross he went out to a place called The Skull, which in Hebrew is Golgotha.
There they crucified him and two others with him, one on each side with Jesus in the middle.
Pilate wrote a sign and put it on the cross; the writing was, "Jesus of Nazareth, The King of the Jews."
Many among the Jews read this sign, for the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city. It was written in Hebrew, Greek, and Latin.
The chief priests of the Jews then said to Pilate, "Do not write, «The King of the Jews,» instead that he said, «I am King of the Jews.»
Pilate answered, "What I have written I have written."
And the soldiers, who crucified Jesus, took his clothes (his tunic, too) and made four parts, one part for each soldier. Now the tunic was seamless woven from the top throughout.

So they said to each other, "Let's not tear it but cast lots for it [to see] whose it will be." [This happened] that the Scripture might be fulfilled which says, "They divided my clothes among them and cast lots for my clothing." That's why the soldiers did these things.
Now Jesus' mother, and his mother's sister, Mary the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene were standing by Jesus' cross.
Then Jesus saw his mother and the disciple, whom he kept loving, standing there; he said to his mother, "Woman, here is your son."
Then he said to the disciple, "Here is your mother." From that hour that disciple took her into his own [home].
After this, Jesus seeing that all things were now completed said (so the Scripture might be fulfilled), "I am thirsty."
A full jar of vinegar was standing there, and they filled a sponge with vinegar, stuck it on a hyssop branch, and put it to his mouth.
Then when Jesus had received the vinegar, he said, "It is finished!" He bowed his head and gave up his spirit.

Because it was Preparation Day, [and] in order that the bodies shouldn't remain on the crosses on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath Day was special), Pilate was asked that their legs be broken and [their bodies] taken away.
So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first and the other one who was crucified with him,
but when they came to Jesus, they saw that he was already dead and didn't break his legs.
One of the soldiers punctured his side with a spear and immediately blood and water came out.
He who watched this bears witness, and his witness is true. He knows what he says is true, so that you may believe.
These things were done so that Scripture would be fulfilled, "Not one of his bones will be broken."
And again another Scripture says, "They will stare at him whom they have pierced."

After this Joseph of Arimathea, a disciple of Jesus but secretly through fear of the Jews, asked Pilate so that he might take away the body of Jesus, and Pilate gave him permission. So he came and took the body of Jesus.
Nicodemus, the one who came to Jesus at night, brought approximately a hundred pound mixture of myrrh and aloes.
Then they took the body of Jesus and wrapped it in linen cloth together with spices, just as is the Jewish custom of burial.
Now by the place where he was crucified, there was a garden, and in that garden [there was] a new tomb where no one had ever been placed.
They laid Jesus there, because of the Jews' Preparation Day, for the tomb was near.
